p: Most of the collected ticks were larvae and nymphs that appeared to belong to H. rufipes in the H. marginatum complex. These results are similar to those of Hoogstraal et al. ( 28) since, in both investigations, nearly all ticks were identified as immatures that appeared to be H. rufipes ( 28). The tick infestation rate of 2.7% that was recorded in this study is also similar to that of Hoogstraal et al. ( 28). They found a tick infestation rate of 3.0% on birds captured in Egypt during their spring migration from East Africa to Europe.
